elements.content: In this contribution we have extended our current research goal of designing functional metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) using bispyrazole type ligands. Accordingly, ten new cobalt-based MOFs have been synthesized using a simple bispyrazole ligand, 4,4′-methylene-bispyrazole (H2MBP), and isophthalic acid (H2IPA) and its four 5-substituted derivatives R-H2IPA (R = COOH, OH, tBu, NH2). The major aim of this study was to validate the mutual influence of temperature and substitutions on the final structural self-assembly. Five different isophthalic acid derivatives were used to study the influence of substituents while each reaction was carried out at two different temperatures to assess the temperature effect. A clear correlation was observed between the reaction temperature and the coordination number of the cobalt atoms which consequently changes the self-assembly pattern. We have also shown that the periodical change in coordination number did bring about some systematic changes in the structural network via secondary building unit selectivity. With the presence of a tunable cavity inside the network, high surface area, and unsaturated metal centers, MOFs show highly encouraging photocatalytic degradation of toxic dye molecule with a potential application in wastewater purification. Another fascinating aspect of this work is the construction of magnetic coordination polymers with the occurrence of a not-so-common MCE behavior of cobalt-based MOF.

elements.content: We present a systematic study of mutually inclusive influences of temperature and substituent of R-H2IPA molecules on the coordination geometry of a metal center in cobalt-MOFs and the consequential changes in crystal packing. MOFs 1−8 showed encouraging photocatalytic degradation of toxic dye molecule with potential application in wastewater purification. Moreover, MOF 2 represents a rare cobalt-based MOF exhibiting MCE behavior.

MOFs 1-8 showed encouraging photocatalytic degradation of toxic dye molecule with potential application in wastewater purification. Moreover, MOF 2 represents a rare cobalt-based MOF exhibiting MCE behavior.

elements.content: The past two decades have seen an upsurge of interest in the studies of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) or coordination polymers (CPs) due to their role as functional materials. Because of their tunable pore size, high surface area, and easy-to-incorporate functional groups and metal center, MOFs find important applications in the field of gas storage and separation, magnetism, sensor, optics, and catalysis. More often than not, such potential bulk properties of MOFs are governed by the dimension and structural topology, which, in turn, depend on the constituents like ligand and metal. One such topology or dimensionality related property would be magnetism. Recently, there has been a great deal of interest in designing magnetic MOFs through the assembly of organic ligands and paramagnetic metals or metal clusters. Of particular interest is the molecular-based magnetic materials having a cryogenic magnetocaloric effect (MCE), because of their potential application as a magnetic refrigerant material. MCE is a magneto thermodynamic phenomenon characterized by the entropy change (ΔS M) in an isothermal process and by the temperature change (ΔT ad) in an adiabatic process as a result of a magnetic field variation. Nevertheless, most of the studies are focused on discrete clusters, not secondary building unit (SBU) based MOFs. Therefore, it will be interesting and worthy to explore MCE in non-cluster-based SBU type Co-based MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The past two decades have seen an upsurge of interest in the studies of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) or coordination polymers (CPs) due to their role as functional materials. Because of their tunable pore size, high surface area, and easy-to-incorporate functional groups and metal center, MOFs find important applications in the field of gas storage and separation, magnetism, sensor, optics, and catalysis. More often than not, such potential bulk properties of MOFs are governed by the dimension and structural topology, which, in turn, depend on the constituents like ligand and metal. One such topology or dimensionality related property would be magnetism. Recently, there has been a great deal of interest in designing magnetic MOFs through the assembly of organic ligands and paramagnetic metals or metal clusters. Of particular interest is the molecular-based magnetic materials having a cryogenic magnetocaloric effect (MCE), because of their potential application as a magnetic refrigerant material. MCE is a magneto thermodynamic phenomenon characterized by the entropy change (ΔS M) in an isothermal process and by the temperature change (ΔT ad) in an adiabatic process as a result of a magnetic field variation. Nevertheless, most of the studies are focused on discrete clusters, not secondary building unit (SBU) based MOFs. Therefore, it will be interesting and worthy to explore MCE in non-cluster-based SBU type Co-based MOFs.

elements.content: Controlling and fine-tuning of network topology with proper choice of metals and meticulous design of organic ligands with suitable functional group and geometry is at the heart of targeted MOF synthesis. Although there are examples wherein the molecules are assembled in a predetermined fashion, prediction of the structural network is largely considered to be serendipitous. Often the control is violated when prior knowledge of the self-assembling process of the molecules does not agree with the resultant predicted network. This may be attributed largely to various reaction conditions like solvent system, stoichiometry, or pH which do control the self-assembling process.
elements.clean_text: Controlling and fine-tuning of network topology with proper choice of metals and meticulous design of organic ligands with suitable functional group and geometry is at the heart of targeted MOF synthesis. Although there are examples wherein the molecules are assembled in a predetermined fashion, prediction of the structural network is largely considered to be serendipitous. Often the control is violated when prior knowledge of the self-assembling process of the molecules does not agree with the resultant predicted network. This may be attributed largely to various reaction conditions like solvent system, stoichiometry, or pH which do control the self-assembling process.

elements.content: One such reaction parameter which often dictates the structural aspects of the CPs is the reaction temperature. This is particularly important for MOFs based on Co, which is well-known for exhibiting external stimulus-dependent coordination geometry. This is often complimented with the contrasting color, primarily resulting from the different coordination geometry, of resultant complexes. Notwithstanding, most of the studies related to coordination number change vis-à-vis reaction temperature are based on traditional coordination complexes with very few known examples of MOFs, primarily because, in order to systematically probe the influence of such a trivial yet critical parameter, one has to choose a system containing a sufficiently large database of structures. A corresponding heuristic approach needs to study these closely related MOFs wherein other factors such as metal ion, ligand functionalities, solvent system, or pH preserves one effect while specifically varying the temperature of the reaction.

elements.content: As far as a set of ligands with similar functionalities is concerned, 5-substituted isophthalic acids are deemed to be the best choice for such systematic investigation. It is noteworthy here that even though the metal-coordinating functional groups (carboxylates) are same, the substituent (R) at the 5-position of isophthalic acids (R-H2IPA) often plays a pivotal structure determining role. The judiciously designed synthesis using a combination of these factors provides us with a unique opportunity to study the mutual effects of temperature and different substituent on the final topology.
elements.clean_text: As far as a set of ligands with similar functionalities is concerned, 5-substituted isophthalic acids are deemed to be the best choice for such systematic investigation. It is noteworthy here that even though the metal-coordinating functional groups (carboxylates) are same, the substituent (R) at the 5-position of isophthalic acids (R-H2IPA) often plays a pivotal structure determining role. The judiciously designed synthesis using a combination of these factors provides us with a unique opportunity to study the mutual effects of temperature and different substituent on the final topology.

elements.content: We are interested in the two-step crystal engineering strategy: (a) generate a set of CPs keeping all other reaction conditions the same except different substituent of isophthalic acid to study the consequential changes that occurred in the crystal packing and (b) repeat these experiments at different temperature, keeping all other reaction conditions the same including the isophthalic acid derivative, to study the consequential changes that occurred in the crystal packing. This convenient and practical approach should enable us to differentiate the effect of substituent and reaction temperature. Clearly, any change in the crystal packing can be linked to the influence of substituent whereas any structural difference between the two set of CPs is a straightforward manifestation of temperature effect.

This convenient and practical approach should enable us to differentiate the effect of substituent and reaction temperature. Clearly, any change in the crystal packing can be linked to the influence of substituent whereas any structural difference between the two set of CPs is a straightforward manifestation of temperature effect.

elements.content: Another important issue, as far as change in crystal packing of metal–organic network is concerned, is the choice of metal ion. In this regard, our recent results suggest that Co-based CPs would be highly relevant for this kind of study. Co­(II) atoms can adopt varied coordination geometries such as octahedral, tetrahedral, square-pyramidal, trigonal-bipyramidal, and square-planar, and these varied geometries are particularly susceptible to external physical stimuli like temperature.
elements.clean_text: Another important issue, as far as change in crystal packing of metal-organic network is concerned, is the choice of metal ion. In this regard, our recent results suggest that Co-based CPs would be highly relevant for this kind of study. Co(II) atoms can adopt varied coordination geometries such as octahedral, tetrahedral, square-pyramidal, trigonal-bipyramidal, and square-planar, and these varied geometries are particularly susceptible to external physical stimuli like temperature.

elements.content: Based on the above-described background, we carried out the synthesis of cobalt-based CPs with one of the simplest pyrazole-based bridging ligand molecules, 4,4′-methylene-bispyrazole (H2MBP), and isophthalic acid (H2IPA) and its four 5-substituted derivatives R-H2IPA (R = COOH, OH, tBu, NH2). Each reaction was repeated at two different temperatures, which led to ten CPs. The differential structural aspects of the CPs of interest, {[Co­(H2MBP)2(IPA)] n ·CH3OH} (1), {[Co­(H2MBP)­(IPA)] n } (2), {[Co1.5(H2MBP)2(TMA)­(H2O)2] n ·3H2O} (3), {[Co­(H2MBP)­(HTMA)] n ·2CH3OH} (4), {[Co0.5(H2MBP)­(OH-HIPA)] n ·H2O} (5), {[Co­(H2MBP)­(OH-IPA)] n ·DMF} (6), {[Co­(H2MBP)2(tBu-IPA)] n ·H2O} (7), {[Co­(H2MBP)­(tBu-IPA)] n ·CH3OH} (8), [Co0.5(H2MBP)­(NH2–HIPA)] n (9), and [Co­(H2MBP)­(NH2–IPA)] n (10), clearly demonstrate the effect of temperature and substituent on the metal coordination geometry in a comprehensible manner (). The periodical occurrence of paramagnetic metal center in polymeric network raises an interesting possibility of generating magnetic materials. Indeed, MOFs 2 and 7 exhibit some interesting magnetic properties including a rare Co-based magnetocaloric effect. In this contribution we also describe the utility of these MOFs for photodegradation of toxic organic dye with a potential application in wastewater purification.
elements.clean_text: Based on the above-described background, we carried out the synthesis of cobalt-based CPs with one of the simplest pyrazole-based bridging ligand molecules, 4,4'-methylene-bispyrazole (H2MBP), and isophthalic acid (H2IPA) and its four 5-substituted derivatives R-H2IPA (R = COOH, OH, tBu, NH2). Each reaction was repeated at two different temperatures, which led to ten CPs. The differential structural aspects of the CPs of interest, {[Co(H2MBP)2(IPA)] n ⋅CH3OH} (1), {[Co(H2MBP)(IPA)] n } (2), {[Co1.5(H2MBP)2(TMA)(H2O)2] n ⋅3H2O} (3), {[Co(H2MBP)(HTMA)] n ⋅2CH3OH} (4), {[Co0.5(H2MBP)(OH-HIPA)] n ⋅H2O} (5), {[Co(H2MBP)(OH-IPA)] n ⋅DMF} (6), {[Co(H2MBP)2(tBu-IPA)] n ⋅H2O} (7), {[Co(H2MBP)(tBu-IPA)] n ⋅CH3OH} (8), [Co0.5(H2MBP)(NH2-HIPA)] n  (9), and [Co(H2MBP)(NH2-IPA)] n  (10), clearly demonstrate the effect of temperature and substituent on the metal coordination geometry in a comprehensible manner (). The periodical occurrence of paramagnetic metal center in polymeric network raises an interesting possibility of generating magnetic materials. Indeed, MOFs 2 and 7 exhibit some interesting magnetic properties including a rare Co-based magnetocaloric effect. In this contribution we also describe the utility of these MOFs for photodegradation of toxic organic dye with a potential application in wastewater purification.

As mentioned above, a two-step crystal engineering strategy was exploited for this study: (a) generate a set of CPs keeping all other reaction conditions same except different substituents of isophthalic acid and (b) repeat these experiments at different temperature, keeping all other reaction conditions the same. Accordingly, a general solvothermal strategy was used for synthesis with a 1:1:1 composition of Co­(NO3)2, H2MBP, and corresponding acids. Further to our investigation strategy, each of these reactions was carried out at two different temperatures (80 °C, 120 °C) to probe the temperature effect on CP synthesis. Indeed, changing the reaction conditions at two different temperatures afforded two distinctly different types of crystals: while pink colored crystals (with odd compound numbers) are isolated at 80 °C, purple colored crystals (with even compound numbers) are obtained at 120 °C (). Single crystal structure analyses reveal that cobalt atoms adopt a coordination number of six for the pink crystals and exhibit octahedral geometry whereas for the purple crystals cobalt atoms adopts lower coordination numbers, either five or four. In order to avoid confusion, throughout the structural description part the color codes of cobalt atoms were used according to their crystal color, i.e., for pink crystals pink color code is used for cobalt atoms and purple color code for purple crystals.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Crystal Structure Description of MOFs 1-10 

As mentioned above, a two-step crystal engineering strategy was exploited for this study: (a) generate a set of CPs keeping all other reaction conditions same except different substituents of isophthalic acid and (b) repeat these experiments at different temperature, keeping all other reaction conditions the same. Accordingly, a general solvothermal strategy was used for synthesis with a 1:1:1 composition of Co(NO3)2, H2MBP, and corresponding acids. Further to our investigation strategy, each of these reactions was carried out at two different temperatures (80 °C, 120 °C) to probe the temperature effect on CP synthesis. Indeed, changing the reaction conditions at two different temperatures afforded two distinctly different types of crystals: while pink colored crystals (with odd compound numbers) are isolated at 80 °C, purple colored crystals (with even compound numbers) are obtained at 120 °C (). Single crystal structure analyses reveal that cobalt atoms adopt a coordination number of six for the pink crystals and exhibit octahedral geometry whereas for the purple crystals cobalt atoms adopts lower coordination numbers, either five or four. In order to avoid confusion, throughout the structural description part the color codes of cobalt atoms were used according to their crystal color, i.e., for pink crystals pink color code is used for cobalt atoms and purple color code for purple crystals.

elements.content: In our earlier reports we have established the recurrence of a unique self-assembly for pyrazole–carboxylic acid mixed ligand system. It is noteworthy here that even for a mixed ligand system containing carboxylic acids, some archetypal metal–carboxylate clusters usually dominate and dictate the topological aspects of MOFs. Bis-pyrazole-based ligands with a unique hydrogen bonded motif with the metal-coordinated carboxylate group buck this trend and lead to the formation of either a discrete M2L2 type metallocyclic motif (M = Co, L = H2MBP) or infinite (M2L2) n type double helical motifs (). Both the motifs are of major significance in this structural series and henceforth are referred to as SBU-I and ext-SBU.
elements.clean_text:
Building Blocks: Secondary Building Unit (SBU) and Extended-SBU

In our earlier reports we have established the recurrence of a unique self-assembly for pyrazole-carboxylic acid mixed ligand system. It is noteworthy here that even for a mixed ligand system containing carboxylic acids, some archetypal metal-carboxylate clusters usually dominate and dictate the topological aspects of MOFs. Bis-pyrazole-based ligands with a unique hydrogen bonded motif with the metal-coordinated carboxylate group buck this trend and lead to the formation of either a discrete M2L2 type metallocyclic motif (M = Co, L = H2MBP) or infinite (M2L2) n  type double helical motifs (). Both the motifs are of major significance in this structural series and henceforth are referred to as SBU-I and ext-SBU.

elements.content: Pink and purple colored crystals of MOFs 1 and 2 are isolated using a common solvothermal reaction of H2MBP with isophthalic acid in the presence of Co­(NO3)2 at 80° and 120 °C, respectively. MOF 1(triclinic P1̅) forms an intriguing 3D non-interpenetrating cross connected ext-SBU-based grid network (). The asymmetric unit consists of two symmetry independent half atoms of Co­(II), two H2MBP, and one IPA molecule along with two free methanol molecules. The Co­(II) ions are octahedrally coordinated to four coplanar N from four H2MBP molecules of ext-SBU motifs () while the other two axial sites are occupied by oxygen atoms from the carboxylate groups of IPA molecule. Topologically the crystal structure can be better described using the concept of secondary building unit (SBU), albeit unusual infinitely extended SBU (ext-SBU). It is noteworthy here that despite a large number of MOF topologies containing various types of SBUs, an infinitely extended SBU-based network hitherto has not been reported. In the present context, the metal coordinated H2MBP molecules form ext-SBUs which are further connected by IPA molecules. Interestingly, the two ext-SBUs connected to two IPA arms propagate in perpendicular directions (a). This kind of orientation leads to an interconnected grid network where two parallel ext-SBUs are connected to the alternative metal centers (b).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of{[Co(H2MBP)2(IPA)] n ⋅CH3OH} (1) and {[Co(H2MBP)(IPA)] n } (2)

Pink and purple colored crystals of MOFs 1 and 2 are isolated using a common solvothermal reaction of H2MBP with isophthalic acid in the presence of Co(NO3)2 at 80° and 120 °C, respectively. MOF 1(triclinic P1̅) forms an intriguing 3D non-interpenetrating cross connected ext-SBU-based grid network (). The asymmetric unit consists of two symmetry independent half atoms of Co(II), two H2MBP, and one IPA molecule along with two free methanol molecules. The Co(II) ions are octahedrally coordinated to four coplanar N from four H2MBP molecules of ext-SBU motifs () while the other two axial sites are occupied by oxygen atoms from the carboxylate groups of IPA molecule. Topologically the crystal structure can be better described using the concept of secondary building unit (SBU), albeit unusual infinitely extended SBU (ext-SBU). It is noteworthy here that despite a large number of MOF topologies containing various types of SBUs, an infinitely extended SBU-based network hitherto has not been reported. In the present context, the metal coordinated H2MBP molecules form ext-SBUs which are further connected by IPA molecules. Interestingly, the two ext-SBUs connected to two IPA arms propagate in perpendicular directions (a). This kind of orientation leads to an interconnected grid network where two parallel ext-SBUs are connected to the alternative metal centers (b).

elements.content: Crystal structure of MOF 1 showing (a) perpendicular orientation of two adjacent SBU-Is, linked to the IPA molecule, and (b) mutually perpendicular orientation of the interconnected grid network.

MOF 2, however, remains the only structure in this series which does not form any SBU. In stark contrast to the previous structure, the IPA molecules in 2 form an infinite one-dimensional sheet. One of the carboxylate groups adopts an unusual syn–anti coordination mode (a) and join two adjacent metal centers, which eventually forms a centrosymmetric binuclear cluster. Such a binuclear cluster of cobalt atoms, facilitated by an unusual syn–anti coordination mode of the carboxylate group, is immensely important from a magnetic exchange interaction point of view, and as discussed in a later section, MOF 2 indeed shows some interesting magnetic behavior.

elements.content: Crystal structure of MOF 2 showing (a) infinite one-dimensional sheet of IPA molecules using syn–anti coordination modes of carboxylates in centrosymmetric binuclear cluster formation and (b) three-dimensional double-walled cage network and the basic unit.
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure of MOF 2 showing (a) infinite one-dimensional sheet of IPA molecules using syn-anti coordination modes of carboxylates in centrosymmetric binuclear cluster formation and (b) three-dimensional double-walled cage network and the basic unit.

elements.content: From a topological pint of view, the binuclear clusters are subsequently interlinked by chelating acid groups and lead to parallel arrangement of a 1D chain of isophthalic acids. On the other hand, four H2MBP molecules coordinate to the two terminals of the centrosymmetric binuclear cluster forming a 3D double-walled cage topology (b).

elements.content: Formation of two different CPs, pink colored 3 and purple colored 4, is a recurrent theme when reactions were performed at 80° and 120 °C respectively, while using H3TMA as the auxiliary ligand. The asymmetric unit of MOF 3 (monoclinic C2/c) contains a full and a half atom of Co­(II), two H2MBP molecules, one TMA molecule, two metal coordinated water molecules, and three water lattice water molecules. The structural analysis reveals an interesting SBU-based three-dimensional porous network formation. The H2MBP molecules coordinate to two metal centers in a familiar M2L2 type fashion. However, the corresponding SBU ((M2L2)2) unit lies between a discrete SBU-I and an infinite ext-SBU (a).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of {[Co1.5(H2MBP)2(TMA)(H2O)2] n ⋅3H2O} (3) and {[Co(H2MBP)(HTMA)] n ⋅2CH3OH} (4)

Formation of two different CPs, pink colored 3 and purple colored 4, is a recurrent theme when reactions were performed at 80° and 120 °C respectively, while using H3TMA as the auxiliary ligand. The asymmetric unit of MOF 3 (monoclinic C2/c) contains a full and a half atom of Co(II), two H2MBP molecules, one TMA molecule, two metal coordinated water molecules, and three water lattice water molecules. The structural analysis reveals an interesting SBU-based three-dimensional porous network formation. The H2MBP molecules coordinate to two metal centers in a familiar M2L2 type fashion. However, the corresponding SBU ((M2L2)2) unit lies between a discrete SBU-I and an infinite ext-SBU (a).

elements.content: Crystal structure of MOF 3 showing (a) the formation of an infinite 1D array of conjoined cubes and (b) role of TMA molecules in vertical expansion of these conjoined cubes to form a 3D non-interpenetrative grid network.
elements.clean_text: 3  Crystal structure of MOF 3 showing (a) the formation of an infinite 1D array of conjoined cubes and (b) role of TMA molecules in vertical expansion of these conjoined cubes to form a 3D non-interpenetrative grid network.

elements.content: As illustrated in b, after a dimer formation ((M2L2)2), two coordinated water molecules terminate the propagation of H2MBP molecules. This leads to an array of parallel strands of (M2L2)2 which are further connected by two carboxylate groups of TMA molecules and form an infinite 1D array of conjoined cubes. The third carboxylate groups of the TMA molecules, on the other hand, adopt a perpendicular orientation with respect to this 1D array of conjoined cubes and connect the vertically expanded parallel strands of (M2L2)2. The overall three-dimensional network results in a highly porous network with a considerable amount of cavity inside the non-interpenetrating network.
elements.clean_text: As illustrated in b, after a dimer formation ((M2L2)2), two coordinated water molecules terminate the propagation of H2MBP molecules. This leads to an array of parallel strands of (M2L2)2 which are further connected by two carboxylate groups of TMA molecules and form an infinite 1D array of conjoined cubes. The third carboxylate groups of the TMA molecules, on the other hand, adopt a perpendicular orientation with respect to this 1D array of conjoined cubes and connect the vertically expanded parallel strands of (M2L2)2. The overall three-dimensional network results in a highly porous network with a considerable amount of cavity inside the non-interpenetrating network.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of MOF 4 (triclinic P1̅) contains a Co­(II) atom, an H2MBP molecule, an HTMA dianion, and two methanol molecules. Interestingly, out of three carboxylic groups of H3TMA, only two underwent deprotonation and coordinate to cobalt atom, the protonated third one however does not coordinate and plays an important role in hydrogen bonded supramolecular network formation. The H2MBP molecules, on the other hand, adopt a favorable M2L2 type self-aggregation and result in SBU-I formation. The HTMA molecules, in turn, act as linkers and clamp the SBU-I from both carboxylate ends and lead to a ladderlike 1D polymeric network (a) with a protruding third unligating carboxylic group.

The HTMA molecules, in turn, act as linkers and clamp the SBU-I from both carboxylate ends and lead to a ladderlike 1D polymeric network (a) with a protruding third unligating carboxylic group.

elements.content: Crystal structure of MOF 4 showing (a) the formation of SBU-I containing ladder type topology and (b) their π–π stacked three-dimensional self-assembly, further supported by solvent mediated hydrogen bonding.
elements.clean_text: 4  Crystal structure of MOF 4 showing (a) the formation of SBU-I containing ladder type topology and (b) their π-π stacked three-dimensional self-assembly, further supported by solvent mediated hydrogen bonding.

elements.content: The hydrogen bonds of the carboxylic acid and π–π stacking play a major role in the self-assembly of these 1D polymeric networks. The aromatic rings of two peripheral HTMA molecules of the 1D chain undergo sidewise π–π stacking with HTMA molecules of the two parallel adjacent chains (b). The supramolecular connectivity between these 1D networks is further promoted by several intermolecular interactions between acid or pyrazole moiety and methanol molecules. Such self-assembly results in a 3D supramolecular network containing distinct solvent occupied one-dimensional nanoporous channels.

The supramolecular connectivity between these 1D networks is further promoted by several intermolecular interactions between acid or pyrazole moiety and methanol molecules. Such self-assembly results in a 3D supramolecular network containing distinct solvent occupied one-dimensional nanoporous channels.

elements.content: Structural investigation reveals that MOF 5 forms an ext-SBU-based 1D polymeric network (). The MOF crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group with one half of a Co­(II) atom, one H2MBP molecule, and one OH-HIPA molecule, along with one water molecule in the asymmetric unit. Out of the two carboxylic groups of the OH-H2IPA, only one coordinates to the metal center while the second one remains protonated and plays an important role in hydrogen bonded supramolecular network formation. The H2MBP molecules adopt a characteristic (M2L2) n type self-aggregation and result in ext-SBU formation while the monodentate OH-HIPA anion, in turn, plays the role of a terminal linker. Interestingly, two monodentate OH-HIPA molecules adopt a winglike orientation and protrude from either side of the cobalt atom. Such orientation brings OH-HIPA molecules of the two adjacent 1D chain very close to each other to interdigitate, sustained by several intermolecular interactions, π–π stacking, and hydrogen bonds.

Crystal Structures of {[Co0.5(H2MBP)(OH-HIPA)] n ⋅H2O} (5) and {[Co(H2MBP)(OH-IPA)] n ⋅DMF} (6)

Structural investigation reveals that MOF 5 forms an ext-SBU-based 1D polymeric network (). The MOF crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group with one half of a Co(II) atom, one H2MBP molecule, and one OH-HIPA molecule, along with one water molecule in the asymmetric unit. Out of the two carboxylic groups of the OH-H2IPA, only one coordinates to the metal center while the second one remains protonated and plays an important role in hydrogen bonded supramolecular network formation. The H2MBP molecules adopt a characteristic (M2L2) n  type self-aggregation and result in ext-SBU formation while the monodentate OH-HIPA anion, in turn, plays the role of a terminal linker. Interestingly, two monodentate OH-HIPA molecules adopt a winglike orientation and protrude from either side of the cobalt atom. Such orientation brings OH-HIPA molecules of the two adjacent 1D chain very close to each other to interdigitate, sustained by several intermolecular interactions, π-π stacking, and hydrogen bonds.

elements.content: Crystal structure of MOF 5 showing (a) ext-SBU-based 1D polymeric network with winglike orientation of acid molecules and (b) π–π stacked self-assembly.
elements.clean_text: 5  Crystal structure of MOF 5 showing (a) ext-SBU-based 1D polymeric network with winglike orientation of acid molecules and (b) π-π stacked self-assembly.

elements.content: The structural network and supramolecular self-assembly of MOF 6, however, closely resemble those of MOF 4, with a similar SBU-I-based ladder type network. The final structural outcome is again dominated by sidewise stacking of adjacent ladder type chains with π–π interactions and several hydrogen bonds ().

The final structural outcome is again dominated by sidewise stacking of adjacent ladder type chains with π-π interactions and several hydrogen bonds ().

elements.content: Crystal structure of MOF 6 illustrating (a) characteristic 1D ladderlike topology and (b) π–π interactions of MOF 6.
elements.clean_text: 6  Crystal structure of MOF 6 illustrating (a) characteristic 1D ladderlike topology and (b) π-π interactions of MOF 6.

elements.content: MOF 7 with tBu-IPA as auxiliary ligand forms an ext-SBU-based three-dimensional interconnected grid network, that closely resembles the framework of MOF 1. MOF 7 (monoclinic P21/c) contains two symmetry independent Co­(II) half atoms, two H2MBP molecules, one tBu-IPA, and one lattice water molecule in the asymmetric unit. The H2MBP molecules form the characteristic 1D helical chain of ext-SBU while the acid molecules connect these ext-SBUs at the alternative metal centers to generate a 2D grid network (). Similar to MOF 1, two ext-SBUs connected to either side of the acid molecule adopt a mutually perpendicular orientation and subsequently cross-link adjacent networks to form a three-dimensional framework.

Crystal Structures of {[Co(H2MBP)2(tBu-IPA)] n ⋅H2O } (7) and {[Co(H2MBP)(tBu-IPA)] n ⋅CH3OH } (8)

MOF 7 with tBu-IPA as auxiliary ligand forms an ext-SBU-based three-dimensional interconnected grid network, that closely resembles the framework of MOF 1. MOF 7 (monoclinic P21/c) contains two symmetry independent Co(II) half atoms, two H2MBP molecules, one tBu-IPA, and one lattice water molecule in the asymmetric unit. The H2MBP molecules form the characteristic 1D helical chain of ext-SBU while the acid molecules connect these ext-SBUs at the alternative metal centers to generate a 2D grid network (). Similar to MOF 1, two ext-SBUs connected to either side of the acid molecule adopt a mutually perpendicular orientation and subsequently cross-link adjacent networks to form a three-dimensional framework.

elements.content:
MOF 8 crystallizes in triclinic P1̅ space group and has the similar ladder type network of MOFs 4 and 6, with familiar π–π stacked supramolecular self-assembly ().

Crystal Structures of [Co<sub>0.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>MBP)­(NH<sub>2</sub>-HIPA)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>9</bold>) and [Co­(H<sub>2</sub>MBP)­(NH<sub>2</sub>-IPA)]<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>10</bold>)

Amine-substituted acids are deemed to be the ideal candidate for studying the role of noncovalent interactions on the final structural outcome. For the present case, two completely different MOFs were obtained with NH2-H2IPA, primarily because of the different roles played by the −NH2 group. With a noncoordinated free −NH2 group, MOF 9 which crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group exhibits a similar ext-SBU-based 1D polymeric network of MOF 5. In a close resemblance to MOF 5, the terminally coordinated monocarboxylate acid molecules once again adopt a winglike orientation and protrude from either side of cobalt atom. The adjacent 1D network is further connected by several hydrogen bonds between the carboxylic and amine groups ().

Amine-substituted acids are deemed to be the ideal candidate for studying the role of noncovalent interactions on the final structural outcome. For the present case, two completely different MOFs were obtained with NH2-H2IPA, primarily because of the different roles played by the -NH2 group. With a noncoordinated free -NH2 group, MOF 9 which crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group exhibits a similar ext-SBU-based 1D polymeric network of MOF 5. In a close resemblance to MOF 5, the terminally coordinated monocarboxylate acid molecules once again adopt a winglike orientation and protrude from either side of cobalt atom. The adjacent 1D network is further connected by several hydrogen bonds between the carboxylic and amine groups ().

elements.content: In MOF 10, the −NH2 group is not free but coordinates to the cobalt atom and brings a drastic change in the resultant network via an unusual (3,3)-type topology (a). MOF 10, however, remains consistent with the theme of this work and exhibits an interesting SBU-I-based pillared-layer network. MOF 10 (triclinic, P1̅) contains one cobalt, an acid molecule, and an H2MBP molecule in the asymmetric unit. The octahedral metal centers are coordinated to two pyrazole moieties, one monodentate and bidentate chelating carboxylate groups, and one amine group.

The octahedral metal centers are coordinated to two pyrazole moieties, one monodentate and bidentate chelating carboxylate groups, and one amine group.

elements.content: Topologically, the crystal structure can be described in terms of a pillared-layer network. A two-dimensional (3,3)-type layer part was formed when coplanar NH2-IPA molecules coordinated to three metal centers (a). The H2MBP molecules, as if to accommodate “pillar” SBU-Is inside the two 2D layers, pairwise coordinate each metal center and sustain the framework.

A two-dimensional (3,3)-type layer part was formed when coplanar NH2-IPA molecules coordinated to three metal centers (a). The H2MBP molecules, as if to accommodate "pillar" SBU-Is inside the two 2D layers, pairwise coordinate each metal center and sustain the framework.

elements.content: The above structural study presents an interesting account on the influence of temperature on the metal coordination geometry and subsequent correlation with the final structural network. There is clear correlation between the reaction temperature and the color of the MOFs, i.e., reactions at 80 °C resulted in pink colored MOFs while purple colored MOFs were obtained when reactions were carried out at 120 °C. Of course, the colors of the MOFs are mere manifestations of the coordination number adopted by the metal ions. Apparently, low temperature reaction leads to coordination number six with an octahedral geometry around the metal center while high temperature reaction yields a coordination number of either four or five with a respective tetrahedral or distorted square pyramidal geometry. From a supramolecular framework perspective, this periodical change in coordination number did bring about some systematic changes in the structural network via a consequential change in secondary building unit formation. For all the MOFs with octahedral cobalt atoms ext-SBU-based structures are observed while lower coordination number primarily led to SBU-I formation. In other words, for the present system, a rare relationship does exist between the reaction temperature and nature of SBU formed, which, in a way, does play a pivotal role in controlling the self-assembly process. Such strategic controllability of the supramolecular self-assembly process via SBU selectivity and subsequently synthesis of a premeditated structural framework with desired topology and dimensionality remains the prime aim of generating functional coordination polymers.

Discussion of Temperature Effect

The above structural study presents an interesting account on the influence of temperature on the metal coordination geometry and subsequent correlation with the final structural network. There is clear correlation between the reaction temperature and the color of the MOFs, i.e., reactions at 80 °C resulted in pink colored MOFs while purple colored MOFs were obtained when reactions were carried out at 120 °C. Of course, the colors of the MOFs are mere manifestations of the coordination number adopted by the metal ions. Apparently, low temperature reaction leads to coordination number six with an octahedral geometry around the metal center while high temperature reaction yields a coordination number of either four or five with a respective tetrahedral or distorted square pyramidal geometry. From a supramolecular framework perspective, this periodical change in coordination number did bring about some systematic changes in the structural network via a consequential change in secondary building unit formation. For all the MOFs with octahedral cobalt atoms ext-SBU-based structures are observed while lower coordination number primarily led to SBU-I formation. In other words, for the present system, a rare relationship does exist between the reaction temperature and nature of SBU formed, which, in a way, does play a pivotal role in controlling the self-assembly process. Such strategic controllability of the supramolecular self-assembly process via SBU selectivity and subsequently synthesis of a premeditated structural framework with desired topology and dimensionality remains the prime aim of generating functional coordination polymers.

elements.content: Organic dyes are one of the largest sources of industrial pollutants and possess a serious environmental threat. These dyes are often found to be nonbiodegradable, toxic, and potentially carcinogenic in nature. One such example would be Congo red, which is mostly used in cellulose industries and eventually generates a considerable amount of wastewater. Removal of such toxic dyes from wastewater has become an important issue in environmental research. However, because of their relatively high photostability and chemical stability, removal of such toxic dyes from wastewater is a challenging task and requires some special treatment. Recently, much attention has been focused on the use of heterogeneous Fenton catalysts to oxidize such contaminants, which largely depends on transition metal based catalysts. With the presence of tunable cavity inside the network, high surface area, and unsaturated metal centers, MOFs have emerged as a new class of photocatalysts for organic dye degradation. Fenton oxidation technologies utilize H2O2, which generates hydroxyl radicals that are very effective in degrading organic pollutants, but the uncatalyzed reaction rates are generally slow at ambient temperature, and activation of H2O2 is necessary to accelerate the process. Here we have used a series of Co-MOFs to study photocatalytic activity of Congo red in aqueous solution. In the presence of Co-MOFs, continuous bleaching of bright red color of the dye () clearly demonstrates the degradation procedure. When MOFs 1–8 were introduced into the system, about 76% of the dye was degraded within 130 min, whereas the control experiment (in absence of Co-MOFs) showed no visual color change of the dye solution within the mentioned time frame. This phenomenon suggested that our Co-MOFs are more efficient to degrade toxic organic dyes. The decoloration process is characterized by a decrease of the absorption peaks located at 498 and 350 nm (). This decrease could be linked to the attacks of radicals OH• on the nitrogen double bond (NN), located mainly at 350 nm, which might be the most reactive site for the oxidation process. A possible degradation mechanism can be suggested as follows: Co II −MOF + H 2 O 2 → Co III −MOF + OH + OH • Co III −MOF + H 2 O 2 → H • O 2 + Co II −MOF + H + azo dye + OH • → oxidation products

Photocatalytic Activity of MOFs 1-8 

Organic dyes are one of the largest sources of industrial pollutants and possess a serious environmental threat. These dyes are often found to be nonbiodegradable, toxic, and potentially carcinogenic in nature. One such example would be Congo red, which is mostly used in cellulose industries and eventually generates a considerable amount of wastewater. Removal of such toxic dyes from wastewater has become an important issue in environmental research. However, because of their relatively high photostability and chemical stability, removal of such toxic dyes from wastewater is a challenging task and requires some special treatment. Recently, much attention has been focused on the use of heterogeneous Fenton catalysts to oxidize such contaminants, which largely depends on transition metal based catalysts. With the presence of tunable cavity inside the network, high surface area, and unsaturated metal centers, MOFs have emerged as a new class of photocatalysts for organic dye degradation. Fenton oxidation technologies utilize H2O2, which generates hydroxyl radicals that are very effective in degrading organic pollutants, but the uncatalyzed reaction rates are generally slow at ambient temperature, and activation of H2O2 is necessary to accelerate the process. Here we have used a series of Co-MOFs to study photocatalytic activity of Congo red in aqueous solution. In the presence of Co-MOFs, continuous bleaching of bright red color of the dye () clearly demonstrates the degradation procedure. When MOFs 1-8 were introduced into the system, about 76% of the dye was degraded within 130 min, whereas the control experiment (in absence of Co-MOFs) showed no visual color change of the dye solution within the mentioned time frame. This phenomenon suggested that our Co-MOFs are more efficient to degrade toxic organic dyes. The decoloration process is characterized by a decrease of the absorption peaks located at 498 and 350 nm (). This decrease could be linked to the attacks of radicals OH⋅ on the nitrogen double bond (NN), located mainly at 350 nm, which might be the most reactive site for the oxidation process. A possible degradation mechanism can be suggested as follows:  1      Co   II   -MOF +   H   2     O   2   →   Co   III   -MOF + OH +   OH   ⋅       2      Co   III   -MOF +   H   2     O   2   →   H     ⋅     O   2   +   Co   II   -MOF +   H   +       3    azo dye +   OH   ⋅   → oxidation products

elements.content: From the plot of ln­(C t /C 0) versus time (Figure S10), we can easily calculate the rate constant (K app) value, which is tabulated in . The different catalytic activities of the title MOFs may be due to the distinct coordination environments around the metal centers. Overall, all the MOFs show higher activity as catalysts to degrade the Congo red azo dye in a Fenton-like process. So, the rate of the reaction was found significantly higher for MOF 4 (degradation efficiency 76.74%) than the other Co-MOFs reported here ( and ). The catalytic activity may originate from the open metal sites, reactive functional groups, and host matrices or nanometric reaction cavities.

elements.content: Variable temperature direct current (dc) magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on crushed microcrystalline samples in the temperature range of 2–300 K, with an applied magnetic field of 0.1 T, and phase purity of the bulk crystalline samples was checked by PXRD (see Supporting Information). The χm T (χm is the molar magnetic susceptibility) versus T plots for MOF 2 () revealed that the χm T value is 2.43 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K, which is much higher than the expected spin only value 1.875 cm3 mol–1 K (S = 3/2, g = 2.0); this is due to the orbital contribution arising from each CoII center. With decreasing temperature the χm T value increases sharply up to 96 K reaching maxima at 2.54 cm3 mol–1 K, and with further cooling the value decreases smoothly down to 2.20 cm3 mol–1 K at 15 K and finally rapidly increases to reach a value of 2.61 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. This type of phenomenon can be demonstrated as ferromagnetic interaction between the adjacent metal centers.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies

Variable temperature direct current (dc) magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on crushed microcrystalline samples in the temperature range of 2-300 K, with an applied magnetic field of 0.1 T, and phase purity of the bulk crystalline samples was checked by PXRD (see Supporting Information). The χm T (χm is the molar magnetic susceptibility) versus T plots for MOF 2 () revealed that the χm T value is 2.43 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K, which is much higher than the expected spin only value 1.875 cm3 mol-1 K (S = 3/2, g = 2.0); this is due to the orbital contribution arising from each CoII center. With decreasing temperature the χm T value increases sharply up to 96 K reaching maxima at 2.54 cm3 mol-1 K, and with further cooling the value decreases smoothly down to 2.20 cm3 mol-1 K at 15 K and finally rapidly increases to reach a value of 2.61 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. This type of phenomenon can be demonstrated as ferromagnetic interaction between the adjacent metal centers.

elements.content: Similar measurements were performed for MOF 7. The χm T versus T plots for MOF 7 () reveal that the χm T value is 2.3025 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K, which is higher than the expected spin only value of 1.875 cm3 mol–1 K (S = 3/2, g = 2.0); this is also because of orbital contribution arising from each Co center. As the temperature is lowered, the χm T value at first increases slightly to a value of 2.407 cm3 mol–1 K at 156 K, and upon further lowering of temperature, the χm T value decreases continuously to 1.55 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. These types of phenomena indicate dominant antiferromagnetic interactions between the Co­(II) centers.

The data follows the Curie–Weiss law with C = 2.392 cm3 mol–1 K and θ = −3.108 K. These data clearly indicate antiferromagnetic interactions between Co­(II) centers.

Evaluation of the MCE for MOF <bold>2</bold>

As observed in MOF 2, the data were fitted in the Curie–Weiss equation in the whole temperature range showing very small positive Weiss constant θ = 1.96 K (), indicating very weak ferromagnetic coupling between Co­(II) centers. This result prompted us to investigate the magnetocaloric effect (MCE) of 2. The field dependence of magnetization curve was measured up to 50 kG in the temperature range of 2–12 K (). Magnetization (M) vs field (H) measurements showed a saturation value of 2.13 Nβ at 2 K in the presence of an applied field of 5 T. The magnetic entropy change of MOF 2 was calculated at various fields and temperatures from magnetization data using the Maxwell equation. Δ S m = ∫ [ ∂ M ( T , H ) / ∂ T ] H ⁡ d H From b, we observed that on lowering of temperature the value of −ΔS m gradually increases. The maximum entropy change was obtained at −ΔS m = 10.94 J kg–1 K–1 for a field change of ΔH = 50 kG at 2 K. So far MCE-based Co-MOFs are extremely rare in the literature.

The impetus for the work presented herein was to systematically study mutually inclusive influences of temperature and substitution on the coordination geometry of a metal center and the consequential changes that occurred in the crystal packing. Accordingly, we have synthesized a series of cobalt-CPs by systematically varying the substituents of R-H2IPA molecules. In order to demonstrate the effect of reaction temperature each reaction was carried out at 80 and 120 °C. In an excellent agreement with our assumptions, two different sets of MOFs with distinctly different colors (pink for low temperature and purple for higher temperature reactions) were formed with a common trend of octahedral geometry (coordination number (CN) 6) for low temperature structure while a tetrahedral (CN 4) or square pyramidal (CN 5) geometry was obtained for high temperature structures. We have also shown that the periodical change in coordination number did bring about some systematic changes in the structural network via SBU selectivity. MOFs 1–8 show highly encouraging photocatalytic degradation of toxic dye molecule with a potential application in wastewater purification. Moreover, MOF 2 represents one of those very few cobalt-based MOFs that exhibit MCE behavior.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The impetus for the work presented herein was to systematically study mutually inclusive influences of temperature and substitution on the coordination geometry of a metal center and the consequential changes that occurred in the crystal packing. Accordingly, we have synthesized a series of cobalt-CPs by systematically varying the substituents of R-H2IPA molecules. In order to demonstrate the effect of reaction temperature each reaction was carried out at 80 and 120 °C. In an excellent agreement with our assumptions, two different sets of MOFs with distinctly different colors (pink for low temperature and purple for higher temperature reactions) were formed with a common trend of octahedral geometry (coordination number (CN) 6) for low temperature structure while a tetrahedral (CN 4) or square pyramidal (CN 5) geometry was obtained for high temperature structures. We have also shown that the periodical change in coordination number did bring about some systematic changes in the structural network via SBU selectivity. MOFs 1-8 show highly encouraging photocatalytic degradation of toxic dye molecule with a potential application in wastewater purification. Moreover, MOF 2 represents one of those very few cobalt-based MOFs that exhibit MCE behavior.

Variable temperature direct current (dc) magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on crushed microcrystalline samples in the temperature range of 2–300 K, with an applied magnetic field of 0.1 T, and phase purity of the bulk crystalline samples was checked by PXRD (see Supporting Information). The χm T (χm is the molar magnetic susceptibility) versus T plots for MOF 2 () revealed that the χm T value is 2.43 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K, which is much higher than the expected spin only value 1.875 cm3 mol–1 K (S = 3/2, g = 2.0); this is due to the orbital contribution arising from each CoII center. With decreasing temperature the χm T value increases sharply up to 96 K reaching maxima at 2.54 cm3 mol–1 K, and with further cooling the value decreases smoothly down to 2.20 cm3 mol–1 K at 15 K and finally rapidly increases to reach a value of 2.61 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. This type of phenomenon can be demonstrated as ferromagnetic interaction between the adjacent metal centers.

Similar measurements were performed for MOF 7. The χm T versus T plots for MOF 7 () reveal that the χm T value is 2.3025 cm3 mol–1 K at 300 K, which is higher than the expected spin only value of 1.875 cm3 mol–1 K (S = 3/2, g = 2.0); this is also because of orbital contribution arising from each Co center. As the temperature is lowered, the χm T value at first increases slightly to a value of 2.407 cm3 mol–1 K at 156 K, and upon further lowering of temperature, the χm T value decreases continuously to 1.55 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K. These types of phenomena indicate dominant antiferromagnetic interactions between the Co­(II) centers.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies

Variable temperature direct current (dc) magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on crushed microcrystalline samples in the temperature range of 2-300 K, with an applied magnetic field of 0.1 T, and phase purity of the bulk crystalline samples was checked by PXRD (see Supporting Information). The χm T (χm is the molar magnetic susceptibility) versus T plots for MOF 2 () revealed that the χm T value is 2.43 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K, which is much higher than the expected spin only value 1.875 cm3 mol-1 K (S = 3/2, g = 2.0); this is due to the orbital contribution arising from each CoII center. With decreasing temperature the χm T value increases sharply up to 96 K reaching maxima at 2.54 cm3 mol-1 K, and with further cooling the value decreases smoothly down to 2.20 cm3 mol-1 K at 15 K and finally rapidly increases to reach a value of 2.61 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. This type of phenomenon can be demonstrated as ferromagnetic interaction between the adjacent metal centers.

Similar measurements were performed for MOF 7. The χm T versus T plots for MOF 7 () reveal that the χm T value is 2.3025 cm3 mol-1 K at 300 K, which is higher than the expected spin only value of 1.875 cm3 mol-1 K (S = 3/2, g = 2.0); this is also because of orbital contribution arising from each Co center. As the temperature is lowered, the χm T value at first increases slightly to a value of 2.407 cm3 mol-1 K at 156 K, and upon further lowering of temperature, the χm T value decreases continuously to 1.55 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. These types of phenomena indicate dominant antiferromagnetic interactions between the Co(II) centers.
